Structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>

<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have the same 3-dimensional (3-D) frameworks with point symbol of {4.6.7<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.8}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7.8}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}. elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel phosphonocarboxylic ligand, 4'-phosphonobiphenyl-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H4pbpdc), was synthesized to construct 4 zinc compounds, namely, {[Zn3(pbpdc)2⋅2R}n (R=C5H12N for 1, C4H10N for 2 and C6H16N for 3) and {[Zn2pbpdc]⋅C6H18N3}n(4), which were characterized by X-ray crystallography, elemental analysis, FTIR and TG. Structures 1 ~ 3 have the same 3-dimensional (3-D) frameworks with point symbol of {4.6.73.8}2{42.6.72.8}2{42.62.7.8}2{42.62.72}. Structure 4 is constructed from a 6-connected metallic cluster and 3-connected phosphonocarboxylic building units resulting in a topology of flu-3,6-C2/c. The luminescent properties of compounds 1 ~ 4 and organic ligand were studied.

They have 2 topologies of {4.6.7<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.8}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7.8}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>} and flu-3,6-<ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, respectively. The roles of organic amines in the formation of frameworks were discussed.<ce:display>

</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Organic amines were used to direct 4 distinct zinc metal-organic frameworks based on a novel phosphonocarboxylate ligand. They have 2 topologies of {4.6.73.8}2{42.6.72.8}2{42.62.7.8}2{42.62.72} and flu-3,6-C2/c, respectively. The roles of organic amines in the formation of frameworks were discussed.

The structures and properties of MOFs are depending on the coordination nature of inorganic ions and the types of organic ligands including carboxylate , imidazolate , phosphonate 
<ce:inf loc="post">,</ce:inf> etc. Metal phosphonates tend to exhibit high thermal and chemical stability, which are important for industrial application. Recently many novel metal phosphonates with promising properties in catalysis, magnetism, gas storage and separation were reported by our group . elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ A novel phosphonocarboxylate ligand was firstly used to synthesize MOFs.   ⋅ Four amine-directed zinc phosphonocarboxylates were obtained.   ⋅ Compound 4 has a rare flu-3,6-C2/c topology.   

A novel phosphonocarboxylate ligand was firstly used to synthesize MOFs.

Four amine-directed zinc phosphonocarboxylates were obtained.

Compound 4 has a rare flu-3,6-C2/c topology.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely studied over the last decades due to their promising applications in the fields including gas storage  and separation , drug delivery , molecular recognition , catalysis , luminescence , magnetism  and so on. The structures and properties of MOFs are depending on the coordination nature of inorganic ions and the types of organic ligands including carboxylate , imidazolate , phosphonate  , etc. Metal phosphonates tend to exhibit high thermal and chemical stability, which are important for industrial application. Recently many novel metal phosphonates with promising properties in catalysis, magnetism, gas storage and separation were reported by our group . The rigid and bifunctional ligands, such as 4-phosphonobenzoic , 3-phosphonobenzoic  and 5-phosphonobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid  have been employed to form novel MOFs with interesting architectures and functionalities. Following the idea of expanding the structures, here we designed an elongate phosphonocarboxylic ligand, 4'-phosphonobiphenyl-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H4pbpdc) to synthesize porous metal phosphocarboxylates. The organic amines are introduced in the syntheses and 4 compounds, namely {[Zn3(pbpdc)2⋅2R}n (R=C5H12N for 1, C4H10N for 2 and C6H16N for 3) and {[Zn2pbpdc]⋅C6H18N3}n (4), were obtained. We discussed the different roles of organic amines and the luminescent properties of 1 ~ 4 were investigated.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were obtained by the similar reaction of zinc acetate and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>pbpdc with the molar ratio of 3:2 under the mixed-solvents of water and ethylene glycol using different organic amines as deprotonated agents (see SI. for details). The organic amines are piperidine, pyrrolidine and triethylamine for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements  revealed that compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
 have the same frameworks except that the amines located in the channels are different. We take <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> as an example to show the structural details. The asymmetric unit of structure <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains 1 and a 1/2 crystallographically unique zinc atoms, 1 pbpdc<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion and 1 protonated piperidine C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). The coordination environments of Zn(II) centers are shown in a. The ligand of pbpdc is bonded to 6 zinc atoms and both Zn atoms are four-coordinated with 2 phosphonate oxygens and 2 carboxylate oxygens with the Zn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bonds ranging from 1.906(3) to 2.006(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a 3-D structure which can be classified into the category of I<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>O<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, where the inorganic chains formed by alternating corner-shared ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC tetrahedrons along the axis (I<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>) are cross-linked by pbpdc along the other 2 axes (O<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) to generate a 3D anion framework. The protonated organic amines were located in the straight channels. The organic amines interact with framework by strong hydrogen bonds (<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">N</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>
<ce:inf loc="post">H···O</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.762(6)–2.822(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The diameter of the channel is 3.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å after considering the Van der Waals radius (Fig. S3). The void volume occupied by the guest molecules is 40.3% as estimated by PLATON . To better understand the structure, the topology was analyzed in detail by using the TOPOS program . As shown in b and c, considering the pbpdc linker as 2 4-connected nodes and Zn as a 4-connected node yield a 3-D 4-nodal net with point symbol of {4.6.7<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.8}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7.8}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>} (d), which is a new topology indicated by TOPOS program.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1 ~ 3 were obtained by the similar reaction of zinc acetate and H4pbpdc with the molar ratio of 3:2 under the mixed-solvents of water and ethylene glycol using different organic amines as deprotonated agents (see SI. for details). The organic amines are piperidine, pyrrolidine and triethylamine for 1 ~ 3, respectively. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements  revealed that compounds 1 ~ 3  have the same frameworks except that the amines located in the channels are different. We take 1 as an example to show the structural details. The asymmetric unit of structure 1 contains 1 and a 1/2 crystallographically unique zinc atoms, 1 pbpdc4- anion and 1 protonated piperidine C5H10NH2 + cation (a). The coordination environments of Zn(II) centers are shown in a. The ligand of pbpdc is bonded to 6 zinc atoms and both Zn atoms are four-coordinated with 2 phosphonate oxygens and 2 carboxylate oxygens with the ZnO bonds ranging from 1.906(3) to 2.006(4)Å. 1 shows a 3-D structure which can be classified into the category of I1O2, where the inorganic chains formed by alternating corner-shared ZnO4 and O3PC tetrahedrons along the axis (I1) are cross-linked by pbpdc along the other 2 axes (O2) to generate a 3D anion framework. The protonated organic amines were located in the straight channels. The organic amines interact with framework by strong hydrogen bonds (d N  H⋅⋅⋅O =2.762(6)-2.822(5)Å). The diameter of the channel is 3.4Å after considering the Van der Waals radius (Fig. S3). The void volume occupied by the guest molecules is 40.3% as estimated by PLATON . To better understand the structure, the topology was analyzed in detail by using the TOPOS program . As shown in b and c, considering the pbpdc linker as 2 4-connected nodes and Zn as a 4-connected node yield a 3-D 4-nodal net with point symbol of {4.6.73.8}2{42.6.72.8}2{42.62.7.8}2{42.62.72} (d), which is a new topology indicated by TOPOS program.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>
 was synthesized using tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (<ce:italic>taea</ce:italic>) under the similar solvothermal condition. It crystallizes in monoclinic space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. As shown in a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>, the asymmetric unit contains 2 zinc atoms, 1 pbpdc<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand and 1 <ce:italic>taea</ce:italic>. The pbpdc<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> shows a five-connected mode different from that in structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Zn1 is four-coordinated with 2 phosphonate oxygens and 2 carboxylate oxygens, including 4 regular Zn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bonds ranging from 1.913(3) to 1.958(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. It is interesting that <ce:italic>taea</ce:italic> acts as a second ligand and coordinated with Zn2 atom, resulting in a trigonal bipyramidal coordinated modes by 1 phosphonate oxygen and 4 nitrogens from <ce:italic>taea</ce:italic>. The distance of Zn2–O is 2.016(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the range of Zn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bonds is from 2.034(5) to 2.332(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The connection between ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, ZnON<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and CPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> forms a four metallic cluster of Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>taea</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (denoted as Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-SBU, SBU: second building unit), which is further linked in 3 directions by the organic parts of pbpdc, resulting in a 3-D framework, which can be classified in the I<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>O<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> category. Considering the Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-SBU as a 6-connected node (b), and pbpdc as a 3-connected node (c), this infinite 3-D framework could be described as a (3,6)-connected network with point symbol {4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>.10<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}, referring to flu-3,6-<ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/c topology (d). To the best of our knowledge, this topology was rarely observed in MOFs and only 4 multi-carboxylate compounds were reported . We have previously reported a (3,6)-connected rutile topology based on 5-phosphonobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid . Using this elongated linker, the new flu-3,6-<ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> topology here is firstly observed in phosphonate-based MOFs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 4  was synthesized using tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (taea) under the similar solvothermal condition. It crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. As shown in a, the asymmetric unit contains 2 zinc atoms, 1 pbpdc4- ligand and 1 taea. The pbpdc4- shows a five-connected mode different from that in structures 1 ~ 3. Zn1 is four-coordinated with 2 phosphonate oxygens and 2 carboxylate oxygens, including 4 regular ZnO bonds ranging from 1.913(3) to 1.958(3)Å. It is interesting that taea acts as a second ligand and coordinated with Zn2 atom, resulting in a trigonal bipyramidal coordinated modes by 1 phosphonate oxygen and 4 nitrogens from taea. The distance of Zn2-O is 2.016(3)Å and the range of ZnN bonds is from 2.034(5) to 2.332(4)Å. The connection between ZnO4, ZnON4 and CPO3 forms a four metallic cluster of Zn4(CO2)4(PO3)2(taea)2 (denoted as Zn4-SBU, SBU: second building unit), which is further linked in 3 directions by the organic parts of pbpdc, resulting in a 3-D framework, which can be classified in the I0O3 category. Considering the Zn4-SBU as a 6-connected node (b), and pbpdc as a 3-connected node (c), this infinite 3-D framework could be described as a (3,6)-connected network with point symbol {42.6}2{44.62.87.102}, referring to flu-3,6-C2/c topology (d). To the best of our knowledge, this topology was rarely observed in MOFs and only 4 multi-carboxylate compounds were reported . We have previously reported a (3,6)-connected rutile topology based on 5-phosphonobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid . Using this elongated linker, the new flu-3,6-C2/c topology here is firstly observed in phosphonate-based MOFs.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">From the structural studies, we notice that organic amines have obvious effects on the structural self-assembly. Generally, the roles of amines include as deprotonation agents, structure-directing agents (SDAs) and nitrogen-donor ligands . As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> can be seen as the constructions from similar primary units of Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> 4-ring. In structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the neighboring 4-rings are connected by corner-sharing with Zn(2)O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> to form an infinite 1-D inorganic chain, which are further linked by the organic parts of the ligand into a 3-D anion I<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>O<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> framework. Here, the piperidine, pyrrolidine and triethylamine act as deprotonation agents and play space filling roles in the formation of those structures. The <ce:italic>pK</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> values of 11.0, 11.3 and 10.7 for piperidine, pyrrolidine and triethylamine are very close . We suppose that the similar basic condition provided by those 3 amines directs the same frameworks from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. However in structure <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, due to the strong coordination ability of <ce:italic>taea</ce:italic>, it acts as a nitrogen-donor ligand and terminates the connection between 4-rings to form an isolate Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-SBU. The inorganic part is 0-D. <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> can therefore be classified in the category I<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>O<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, which is a classical construction way of carboxylate MOFs and rarely observed in phosphonate MOFs. It is concluded that the organic amines with different alkalinities or coordination abilities can be used to design varieties of metal phosphonocarboxylate frameworks for further exploration.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From the structural studies, we notice that organic amines have obvious effects on the structural self-assembly. Generally, the roles of amines include as deprotonation agents, structure-directing agents (SDAs) and nitrogen-donor ligands . As shown in  , compounds 1 ~ 4 can be seen as the constructions from similar primary units of Zn2P2 4-ring. In structures 1 ~ 3, the neighboring 4-rings are connected by corner-sharing with Zn(2)O4 to form an infinite 1-D inorganic chain, which are further linked by the organic parts of the ligand into a 3-D anion I1O2 framework. Here, the piperidine, pyrrolidine and triethylamine act as deprotonation agents and play space filling roles in the formation of those structures. The pK a values of 11.0, 11.3 and 10.7 for piperidine, pyrrolidine and triethylamine are very close . We suppose that the similar basic condition provided by those 3 amines directs the same frameworks from 1 to 3. However in structure 4, due to the strong coordination ability of taea, it acts as a nitrogen-donor ligand and terminates the connection between 4-rings to form an isolate Zn4-SBU. The inorganic part is 0-D. 4 can therefore be classified in the category I0O3, which is a classical construction way of carboxylate MOFs and rarely observed in phosphonate MOFs. It is concluded that the organic amines with different alkalinities or coordination abilities can be used to design varieties of metal phosphonocarboxylate frameworks for further exploration.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are similar and all PXRD patterns closely match that of simulated patterns based on the single-crystal X-ray data, suggesting the purities of bulk samples (Figs. S4 and S5). Thermogravimetric analysis under nitrogen atmosphere show nearly no weight loss up to 210, 200, 220 and 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, respectively (Fig. S6). The subsequent departures of organic amine and ligand are continuous after the onset temperature. The total weight losses for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are 57.8% (calc. 61.6%), 58.8% (calc. 60.5%), and 61.1% (calc. 62.7%) respectively. The residues for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are considered as Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The curve of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> doesn't reach to a stable trough, indicating the incomplete decomposition at 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1 ~ 3 are similar and all PXRD patterns closely match that of simulated patterns based on the single-crystal X-ray data, suggesting the purities of bulk samples (Figs. S4 and S5). Thermogravimetric analysis under nitrogen atmosphere show nearly no weight loss up to 210, 200, 220 and 250°C for compounds 1 ~ 4, respectively (Fig. S6). The subsequent departures of organic amine and ligand are continuous after the onset temperature. The total weight losses for 1 ~ 3 are 57.8% (calc. 61.6%), 58.8% (calc. 60.5%), and 61.1% (calc. 62.7%) respectively. The residues for 1 ~ 3 are considered as Zn3(PO4)2. The curve of 4 doesn't reach to a stable trough, indicating the incomplete decomposition at 800°C.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Along with the insolubility in common inorganic or organic solvents, the solid-state photoluminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were investigated at room temperature, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>. The free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>pbpdc ligand displays 1 emission peak at 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm under excitation at 310<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Using the same excitation, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit close emission peaks at 373, 367 and 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively. The above results suggest that the emissions might come from the π–π* interactions between the aromatic rings of the pbpdc ligand. The spectra of compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> excited between 340 and 410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm were also measured (Fig. S7). Additional broad-band emission at about 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm was observed, which may be ascribe to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Along with the insolubility in common inorganic or organic solvents, the solid-state photoluminescent properties of compounds 1 ~ 4 were investigated at room temperature, as shown in  . The free H4pbpdc ligand displays 1 emission peak at 370nm under excitation at 310nm. Using the same excitation, compounds 1 ~ 3 exhibit close emission peaks at 373, 367 and 370nm, respectively. The above results suggest that the emissions might come from the π-π* interactions between the aromatic rings of the pbpdc ligand. The spectra of compound 4 excited between 340 and 410nm were also measured (Fig. S7). Additional broad-band emission at about 450nm was observed, which may be ascribe to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">In summary, a novel phosphocarboxylate ligand was designed and synthesized to form zinc metal-organic frameworks. Four organic amines were introduced to direct 2 kinds of frameworks. In compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>~<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the organic amines with close alkalinities result in the same frameworks and play space filling roles. In structure <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:italic>taea</ce:italic> acts as a nitrogen-donor ligand and terminates the coordination of zinc to form a flu-3,6-<ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> topology. The further studies about MOFs based on this elongate phosphonocarboxylic ligand are on progress, which will give rise to porous crystalline materials with novel topologies and interesting properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, a novel phosphocarboxylate ligand was designed and synthesized to form zinc metal-organic frameworks. Four organic amines were introduced to direct 2 kinds of frameworks. In compounds 1 ~ 3, the organic amines with close alkalinities result in the same frameworks and play space filling roles. In structure 4, taea acts as a nitrogen-donor ligand and terminates the coordination of zinc to form a flu-3,6-C2/c topology. The further studies about MOFs based on this elongate phosphonocarboxylic ligand are on progress, which will give rise to porous crystalline materials with novel topologies and interesting properties.

</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0045">Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Supplementary data to this article can be found online at <ce:inter-ref id="ir0020" xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2013.09.030" xlink:type="simple">http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2013.09.030</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="sp0065" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out on a Bruker APEX DUO diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Data reduction was performed with the SAINT and absorption corrections were applied by the SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods by using the SHELXS program and refined with SHELXL program [25]. Heavy atoms and other non-hydrogen atoms are directly obtained from different Fourier maps. The final refinements were performed by the full-matrix least-square method with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. The hydrogen atoms were added theoretically, which rode on the concerned atoms, and were not refined. CCDC 934851 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 948115 (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), 934849 (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), and 934850 (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via <ce:inter-ref id="ir0025" xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

                               

Supplementary material

Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2013.09.030.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out on a Bruker APEX DUO diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) at 293K. Data reduction was performed with the SAINT and absorption corrections were applied by the SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods by using the SHELXS program and refined with SHELXL program [25]. Heavy atoms and other non-hydrogen atoms are directly obtained from different Fourier maps. The final refinements were performed by the full-matrix least-square method with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. The hydrogen atoms were added theoretically, which rode on the concerned atoms, and were not refined. CCDC 934851 (1), 948115 (2), 934849 (3), and 934850 (4) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1 ~ 3 are similar and all PXRD patterns closely match that of simulated patterns based on the single-crystal X-ray data, suggesting the purities of bulk samples (Figs. S4 and S5). Thermogravimetric analysis under nitrogen atmosphere show nearly no weight loss up to 210, 200, 220 and 250°C for compounds 1 ~ 4, respectively (Fig. S6). The subsequent departures of organic amine and ligand are continuous after the onset temperature. The total weight losses for 1 ~ 3 are 57.8% (calc. 61.6%), 58.8% (calc. 60.5%), and 61.1% (calc. 62.7%) respectively. The residues for 1 ~ 3 are considered as Zn3(PO4)2. The curve of 4 doesn't reach to a stable trough, indicating the incomplete decomposition at 800°C.

Along with the insolubility in common inorganic or organic solvents, the solid-state photoluminescent properties of compounds 1 ~ 4 were investigated at room temperature, as shown in  . The free H4pbpdc ligand displays 1 emission peak at 370nm under excitation at 310nm. Using the same excitation, compounds 1 ~ 3 exhibit close emission peaks at 373, 367 and 370nm, respectively. The above results suggest that the emissions might come from the π-π* interactions between the aromatic rings of the pbpdc ligand. The spectra of compound 4 excited between 340 and 410nm were also measured (Fig. S7). Additional broad-band emission at about 450nm was observed, which may be ascribe to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT).

Crystal data for 1: C38H38N2O14P2Zn3, M=1004.89, orthorhombic, space group Pbcn, a=20.458(3)Å, b=12.1157(17)Å, c=16.971(2)Å, α=β=γ=90° V=4206.5(10)Å 3, Z=4, Dc=1.587gcm-3, F(000)=2048, Rint=0.1166, Final R1=0.0471, wR2=0.0859 [for selected data with I>2σ (I)], GOF=0.960 for all data.
